title: Predicting the Present with Search Engine Data
segmentation: And it's a great pleasure to be here talking with you today.
I want to tell you about some work we're doing in my group at Google.
But before I do that, I have a quiz.
I have a little test for the audience.
I know this has been an exciting convention.
I expect that many of you went out last night and celebrated a great two days.
So it made me consider the following issue.
What day of the week do you suppose there are the most searches for hanging?
Work.
Now, some people say Sunday and some people say Monday every night, and people say Wednesday, Thursday, all sorts of different things.
How would you find out?
Well, in this audience it would be pretty easy.
You know you would go to Google.
And in particular, you go to this service we offer called Google Trends and for Google Trends you can enter any query and Google trends will give you an index of the level of activity.
My query so this is what it looks like.
You can see it's a very regular pattern.
It turns out it peaks every Sunday and that big outlier that's January 1st.
Down below, if you look at the map you can see the normalized frequency of queries on hangover by state and in this case New York State turns out to be the hangover capital of the US.
And finally, on the right hand side you can see the most popular queries, which in this case turned out to be cure for hangover, hangover cure and so on.
So this is a great little tool.
It's lots of fun fact.
You can spend many hours typing things in looking for patterns, and of course you can also download this data yourself.
Just click on the little gear and you can download the time series as a CSV file.
You can also look at multiple queries.
So here's one where we looked at hangover and vodka.
And maybe not too surprisingly, vodka peaks every Saturday and hangover peaks every Sunday and there again, the big outlier is New Year's Eve.
OK. You could play with, do lots of different things with this.
Here's one more example.
Here's gift for boyfriend and gift for girlfriend.
So the red is gift for girlfriend.
Blue is gift for boyfriend leading up to Christmas time.
You can see there both shopping for each other over the course of the holiday period.
But now look look what happens once they get married.
You see?
This rather panicked bulge a few days before Christmas.
A gift for wife gift for wife.
What could I get?
And it's kind of a fun example.
There are many other things like this.
Well, you, you, I urge you to play with yourself to see what you could do.
But what we want to do is something a little more serious.
We want to use that Google trends data to look at economic time series.
And, you know, Yogi Berra said prediction is hard, especially about the future.
So we're going to lower the bar and we're going to try to look at what economists called now casting.
We're going to try to do contemporaneous forecasting.
And you might ask, well, why is contemporaneous forecasting interesting?
And the reason is the economic data is released with a lag, so you don't find out what auto sales were in May until sometime in June, usually about halfway into June.
GDP is only reported quarterly, every three months.
Many statistics are released with at least a month lag and understanding the early read on what those statistics statistics might be.

Is very helpful, so maybe half through half way through May you could look at the queries related to auto purchase decisions or auto purchase shopping and get some idea of what those statistics will look like when the reported later on in June.
So we call this now casting.
So in particular things like unemployment could be related could be predicted by things like job search queries or auto purchase predicted by vehicle shopping queries.
And typically it's going to be a contemporaneous relationship not.
Always, because there are some kinds of searches that precede the activity by several weeks or months.

So if you look at destination planning for a vacation, or you look at something like how shopping, then you might think that the activity that occurs in a given month would be predictive of what would happen two or three months later.
And I'll talk about some of the things we've done in that area in a minute.
Now the problem with this is that it's what you might call a fat regression problem.
There are hundreds of millions or billions of queries and there are many, many more predictors and observations.

So we need a way to do the variable selection Now, even if you're going to look at categories of queries so we can reduce the dimensionality just by classifying those queries into different categories.
We still have about 600 categories at the deepest level.
Roughly 300 categories or so at the.

Mid level range something like 30 categories at the top level range and there's still a lot of categories that you would use for these series and the data only goes back to 2004 so you have roughly 100 observation, then several 100 predictors.
So the challenge is how do you choose which variables to include?
And I know there are many different methods I'm going to talk about the method that we use, but I think this is an interesting area for research, so if you have your favorite method.
I would encourage you to apply it to this problem.
Now sometimes you can do something pretty simple like using this tool.
Google correlate.
So with Google correlate you can feed in anytime series.

This was developed actually for the Google flu trends, but you could in this case we feed in economic time series and we can find those queries to specific queries that are most highly correlated with the time series that you feed in.
So in this particular case I took initial claims for unemployment benefits.
So this is when somebody first becomes unemployed.
They go to the unemployment office.
They file a claim to receive unemployment benefits.
This is reported by the Bureau of Labor Statistics on a weekly basis.

I feed this data into Google correlate and it comes back with 100 different queries that are highly correlated with that particular time series, and one of them in the top of the list is sign up for unemployment.
So you can just imagine when somebody becomes unemployed, they go to their computer.
How do I sign up for unemployment?
Where do I sign up for unemployment?
How long does unemployment last etc etc.
And you can see the correlation between those two series which is shown in the screenshot.
Here is really very high the.
Red is sign up for unemployment and the blue is initial claims for unemployment benefits, as reported by the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
So it certainly looks like those series are addictive.
Now we want to.
Build a little statistics into this.

We can take the D Seasonalized initial claims, so this is taking that initial claims data and taking out the seasonal component, which is really quite strong, but people normally are interested in the DCS allies data.
And then you could take the DCS and lies Detrended searches for the term sign up for unemployment.
Run a base regression which is just saying how well can you predict unemployment claims this month or this week based on what they were last week.

So that's the baseline model and then we add in this extra predictor which is going to be the activity on the term sign up for unemployment and we ask her ourselves how much better can we predict the current initial claims for unemployment which will be reported next week using the.
Data that we have available now, which is the current level of queries and last week's level of initial claims for unemployment benefits.
So we estimate this model using a rolling window where we estimate up to time T, then forecast the next week estimate up to T + 1, forecast T + 2, and so on.
So you're always doing a one step ahead out of sample forecast, and if you do that, it turns out the one step ahead being absolute error during the recession.
During this.
When we saw this big rise in unemployment that you see in this chart is about 8.7% lower.
When you include that, sign up for unemployment query alright?
So it is helpful in terms of improving this one step ahead forecast.
Now that certain nice case worked out pretty easily, I did a very naive model.
I'm going to do something a little more elaborate in a few minutes.
But I also want to point out that sometimes it doesn't work out that well.
So for example, this is a picture of US auto sales, non seasonally adjusted and that great Big Blue outlier is in fact a real data point.
It's when Chrysler and GM went bankrupt, so there weren't any sales during a given month for those for those brands at least.
And I said, did Google correlate?
What is the query?
That's the most highly correlated with that series, and it came back and said the query this most highly most correlated with that series is Indian restaurants.
OK. Now, I had never realized how seasonal Indian restaurants were.
It turns out the queries peak in the summer and just like US auto sales, they also peak in the summer.

They go way down in the winter and if you look at those two series you can see yes indeed they are highly correlated, but they are highly correlated only because they share the same seasonal component.
And what you're really interested in in general is not how correlated that you are taking account of seasonality.
Be wanna know how correlated the nancys D season lines data is.
That is, there's a blip in one show up as a blip in the other.
So the challenge then?
How do you avoid this kind of spurious correlation?
So the typical way to do that is what time series people call whitening the data.
You would build a model for the predictable part of the time series series, just using its own past history.
So you build a model that takes account of trend and seasonality, forecast that serious look at the residuals from that model.
That's the whitened series where we take out the trend and seasonality, and then we want to find the regressors.
Or we want to find predictors that end up predicting the residuals after removing that trend and seasonality.
So that's the kind of conventional model you want to know.
If an innovation or a deviation from the past pattern of behavior of Series A is predictive of the deviation or past pattern deviation from past pattern of series B.

So how do you choose regression or simple correlation is too limited and of course human judgment of kind of looking at these models and seeing whether there's a plausible relationship that doesn't scale.
So we want to figure out how to automate this process insofar as possible.
Now.
Economists, I have to say mostly.
We're working on small problems.
Mostly we use human judgment, but there is a lot of other methods are more.
Flexible in terms of automation, significance testing, forward backward stepwise regression using complexity criteria like AIC and BISITA.

Kind of penalized regression's that are overly complex dimensionality reduction like principle, common components, factor models, partial least squares, and then there are a number of methods for machine learning, which I expect this crowd is all familiar with.
Penalized regressions like Lasso, Lars, Ridge regression, elastic net.
And so on.
So there are many, many different ways to look at variable selection.
We have a particular one that we like is something called Spike.
And slab regression.
So here's how it works.
We call this system Bayesian Structural Time series.
We take classic time series techniques and decompose the series into a trend part, a seasonal part, and then a regression part.
The regression part is the part that's correlated with our proposed regressors.
In detail, we use a common filter to model the trend and seasonality component, so that's kind of subtracting out what you could learn from just the own past history of the time series.
And then we use something called a spike and slab regression for the variable selection and I'll go out in a minute to tell you what that means.
We estimate that whole system using a Markov chain Monte Carlo simulation of the posterior distribution.
And then we use a Bayesian model averaging over the entire ensemble of forecasts that we get from this model.
I'm going to explain each of those.
Pieces in the next 10 minutes or so.
Alright.
The challenge?
And all this is because we have so many variables, so many possible predictors and relatively few observations.
The danger is always overfitting.
So how do we deal with that overfitting?
Well, we use that common filter to whiten the series so that removes the common seasonality and trend.
So you've taken that out and you want to find regressors that are used to predict the residuals.
That is the deviation from the seasonality and trend.

Simultaneous or I described this as if we're doing one Step 2 step, three steps, but it's all done at once in the model and it's the same spirit is something that the economists refer to as Granger causality, which is not really causality.
It's a method of trying to decide whether one series is helpful in predicting another series, and it involves this kind of whitening process that I alluded to earlier.

Now, one thing you can do with this is is you do get these spurious correlations when you use this method, you get many fewer spurious correlations, so you would just without adjusting the data, but one of the filters you can apply is looking at one time events, so we were using this to look at some financial data once on the Wall Street Crash in 2008.
And we found out that one of the predictors for the Wall Street crash were queries on high energy physics.
And they seem very, very strange to us.
So we went and looked at the data.

Turns out the same day that the Wall Street crash Ikerd there was a report from CERN that they were trying to create a black hole and the concern and the story was it might suck up the entire Earth into this black hole and maybe people thought it is already started on Wall Street.

But of course, that kind of query is unlikely to be predictive of anything in the future, because it's clearly a one time event, so trying to subtract out those one time events is, I think, is perfectly fair from the viewpoint of building a predictive model.
And then you could also apply human judgment, but we want to be able to do that in a flexible way, and that's where having a Bayesian model is very helpful.
So you can create a prior.
You can use a prior to suggest the likely number of Regressors saying try to keep this model small.
Or regressive regressive categories that you think will be particularly helpful.
And then finally in this model that naturally produces many thousands of forecasts and you're averaging over all those forecasts in order to get a final prediction.
As we all know, the ensemble estimation also helps to reduce the overfitting problem.

the B or BT in this equation also evolves according to a random walk and then of course in this particular case we make the regression just.

So it's a pretty nice way to do it, and doing this kind of common modeling ends up being very, very robust.
So there's no problem with.
Unit roots or other kinds of nonstationarity when you look at other methods of time series estimation, there's a problem with series that kind of drift off one way or the other.
It's not a issue here, no problem with missing observations.

Turns out, if there were missing observations, same method works just fine in the common approach, the future is what's missing, so if you're trying to forecast, you're trying to fill in the future observations, but if you have a few past observations or missing, no problem there.
No problem with mixed frequency if you're trying to look at weekly data to forecast a monthly time series that all fits in the framework very, very well.
You don't have to do what's called differencing or identification stage in lots of time series models.

You go through a process where you try to 1st make this series stationary so it doesn't drift off this way or that way and then once the stationary you apply the statistical methods so it's easy to automate.
It's got a very nice Bayesian.
Interpretation, it's easy to compute the estimates.

You have a nice interpretation of the structural Components Time series decomposes in a clean way into level, trend and seasonal components.

It's not always the best forecast performance, but the best forecast performance might involve searching through a whole variety of models.

And we estimate a posterior distribution for the for the pair gamma, beta, OK.

So the way that works is when you write down your model, you draw from the posterior distribution you first you gotta gamma, which tells you which variables are in the regression and then conditional on being in you sort of draw a sample out of the betas and then you get the betas that are the coefficients in the of those predictors.
So you simulate the draws from the posterior using a Markov chain Monte Carlo technique that gives you the gammas that gives you the betas.
Make a forecast of Y given those coefficients.
You do this thousands of times, then you get a distribution of posterior distribution for the wise, and then if you want to get a point forecast you can just take the average over the draws.

For the final prediction, and if you want to see which variables tend to be included in the regression, you just take an average over all those draws of gamma, and that tells you which predictors have a high probability or low probability of being included in the regression.
